answers.author: Ian Coyle
answers.text:
Scott - some thoughts --- 1)  make certain the business recruitment strategy you're taking is aligned with the Board/Council's vision of what kind/type of business is "wanted" in the community.  2) don't underestimate power of a web-based presence.  The site should contain information developers, site selectors and/or businesses want --- like zoning laws, comprehensive plans, pictures, contacts, etc.  3) look to start a local development corporation to assist with microenterprise, fund-raising, etc.

Hi Scott,
I have attached a file with the names of local governments that identified business attraction as an economic development goal and their answers to specific questions about their strategy. They all have a written business attraction plan.  You will be able to tell from the column heads which survey questions and answers the spreadsheet shows. There is also contact information. Although these local governments are between 10,000 and 12,000 population, the information might still be useful to you. If you have any questions, feel free to email me at emoulder@icma.org
Best regards,

author: Scott Pingel
text: We are recruiting businesses to town, and I was wondering if anyone has a good or better approach to getting the word out about the City and the potential for businesses to find a niche and thrive. How much should the City being doing to attract certain kinds of the business, and how much should we leave to land owners to do?
title: Small Town (less than 5000) Business Recruitment
